xxl.cursors
Class Minimator

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Aggregator
        |
        +--xxl.cursors.Minimator
public class Minimator
extends Aggregator

The Minimator is an Aggregator that computes the minimal object for a given input-Iterator. (lazy evaluation)
The Minimator uses MapEntries to arrange the objects. So the next and peek method return MapEntries.
These MapEntries can be generated with the help of the Function, named mapping, in one constructor, e.g. this function is the identity, if it is not specified by the caller.
Further a Comparator can be specified to compare a MapEntry's key to the value determined by applying the mapping Function to an object of the input-Iterator.
If no Comparator is specified in a constructor, the default Comparator, namely ComparableComparator.DEFAULT_INSTANCE, will be used instead.
The Minimator computes the next minimal element concerning the underlying Cursor by lazy evaluation. If the Minimator is already initialized the result-object is computed by applying the Function on the aggregate, the result-object itself, and the Cursors's next element. Else a new MapEntry will be created as result-object with the help of the mapping Function and then the Cursor's next element is inserted there by adding it to a LinkedList.
Therefore the input-Cursor's absolut minimal object is determined after the caller completely traversed the input-Cursor for one time.
Note: The input-Iterator is wrapped to a Cursor in class Aggregator. A Minimator can also be used as a Maximator by specifying an InverseComparator in a constructor. (see example (2))

Example usage (1): 

 	Minimator minimator = new Minimator(new RandomIntegers(100, 10));
 	while(minimator.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(((MapEntry)minimator.next()).getKey() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 	minimator.close();
This Minimator returns the minimal key of 10 random integers with range [0,...,100[. The next method returns a MapEntry-object which is used to return the minimal key by applying the method getKey. The elements of the Minimator are compared by a ComparableComparator.DEFAULT_INSTANCE, because no other comparator has been specified. But be aware that lazy evaluation is used and therefore the absolute minimum is definitively determined, when all elements in the Minimator have been consumed.

Example usage (2): 

 	Object[] persons = new Object[]{
 		new Object[]{new String("Tobias"), new Integer(23)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Juergen"), new Integer(23)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Martin"), new Integer(26)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Bjoern"), new Integer(28)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Jens"), new Integer(27)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Bernhard"), new Integer(35)},
 		new Object[]{new String("Jochen"), new Integer(29)},
 	};// Object[0] --> name, Object[1] --> age
 	minimator = new Minimator(new ArrayCursor(persons),
 		new Function () {
 			public Object invoke (Object person) {
 				return (Integer)((Object[])person)[1];
 			}
 		},
 		InverseComparator.DEFAULT_INSTANCE
 	);
 	Cursor results = EmptyCursor.DEFAULT_INSTANCE;
 	while(minimator.hasNext()) {
 		results = new IteratorCursor(((LinkedList)((MapEntry)minimator.next()).getValue()).listIterator(0));
 		while(results.hasNext())
 			System.out.print("Name: "+((Object[])results.next())[0] +"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 	}
 	minimator.close();
This Minimator uses an ArrayCursor which contains Object arrays and each Object array defines a person in the following way: Object[0] returns the name of a person and Object[1] returns the age of a person.
The defined function maps an input-object(person) to a certain value, namely the person's age. These values are compared with an InverseComparator.DEFAULT_INSTANCE, i.e. the person with the maximum age will be returned by the Minimator by lazy evalutation.
. But be aware that a Minimator returns MapEntry-objects so the next element returned by a Minimator has to be casted to MapEntry. The key of the returned MapEntry-objects is the person's age. With the intention to receive the value of the returned MapEntry, a LinkedList of objects added to the key belonging to this value, this value has to be casted to a LinkedList and for further use this LinkedList is converted to an Iterator by calling its method listIterator(). This iterator is wrapped to a Cursor (results) and the elements of this cursor, are completely consumed. The consumed elements are Object arrays (persons), so the name of each person belonging to the key (age) is printed to the output stream.

See Also:
Comparator, Iterator, LinkedList, Function, Aggregator, ComparableComparator, MapEntry, ComparableComparator

Method Detail

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element is the next minimal element concerning the underlying Cursor.
If the Minimator is already initialized the result-object is computed by applying the Function on the aggregate, the result-object itself, and the Cursors's next element.
Else a new MapEntry will be created as result-object with the help of the mapping Function and the the Cursor's next element is inserted there by adding it to a LinkedList. By calling the next method the returned element will be removed from the underlying collection.
Overrides:
next in class Aggregator
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection. (optional operation)
The underlying Cursor's next element, computed with the Cursor's peek method is added to a new LinkedList.
If the Minimator is initialized then it returns the MapEntry-object, which results in applying the Function to aggregate on the Cursor's next element. Else a new MapEntry-object is created with the help of the mapping Function and the LinkedList.
Overrides:
peek in class Aggregator
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this Minimator.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns false because the peek-operation is not supported by Minimators.
Overrides:
supportsPeek in class Aggregator
Returns:
false if the peek operation is not supported by this Minimator.
